    - As of the date of RMP filing, there have not been any incident investigations associated with

        documentation processes in place for future incident investigations.  
(k) The date of the most recent change that triggered a review or revision of safety information,

     - N/A.  There have not been any changes that triggered changes to the noted procedures and 
         plans since facility startup in January 2024.

Section 4  Five-year Accident History
      - The GGT commenced operation on February 1, 2024. There have been no RMP-relevant 
          accidents at GGT since startup through the submittal if this Risk Management Plan.

or certification, and severity of hazards and potential safety / environmental impacts

         power-point presentation, video, etc.) are also determined based on the detail required to 
         convey the necessary training objective and information to trainee in a clear and consistent 
         manner.
(2) The type of competency testing used. 
    - Evaluation of employee comprehension of training is completed by written exam, oral exam, 
       observation of job performance/demonstration or a combination of methods. In order to 
       complete any initial, refresher or job-specific training, the employee must successfully 
       complete required examinations. If the employee scores less than 80%, the employee will 
       receive additional instruction and be re-tested.
(h) The date of the most recent review or revision of maintenance procedures and the date of the 
       most recent equipment inspection or test and the equipment inspected or tested. 
    - GGT most recently updated maintenance procedures in December 2023.  GGT views these 
       procedures as evergreen and will update on as-needed basis.  All maintenance procedure 
       changes will follow management of change process.  
    - GGT has numerous equipment inspection procedures.  These procedures were last updated 
       in November or December 2023, prior to facility startup in January 2024.  The most recent 
       testing of safety equipment associated with regulated substance storage occurred on 
       February 21, 2024 jointly with the Storey County Fire Protection District, focusing on fire 
       safety systems.
(i) The date of the most recent compliance audit, the expected date of completion of any 
      changes resulting from the compliance audit. 
    - Compliance audits are required every three (3) years (per 68.58(a)).  Since GGT commenced

events and to ensure proper 
      grounding/over fill protection is in place to minimize risks. A high-high level alarm in liquid 
      tanks results in all of the power receptacles being de-energized to stop all of the pumps. A 
      high-high pressure on a pressure indicator transmitter on a pump discharge for 
      propane/butane turns the associated pump off to prevent an over pressure abnormal 
      operating condition (AOC)
(4) Mitigation systems in use
      - Firewater system
      - Manual fixed firewater monitors in the bullet tank area
      - Uninterruptible power supply for the programmable logic control (PLC) system
      - Actuated valves equipped with N2 allowing valves to fail closed
      - Emergency flare system
(5) Monitoring and detection systems in use
      - Operators wear four-gas monitors at all times 
      - Combustible gas sensors 
      - Audible and visual alarms
      - Flame/heat detectors  The fire control panel in the control room (equipped with backup 
           power system) monitors these detectors, and will alarm locally plus automatically notify 
           Storey County Fire Protection District in the event that flame or high heat levels are 
           detected.
(6) Changes since the last hazard review. 
      - The last hazard review was pre-startup, and as of the date of RMP filing, no additional 
           hazard reviews have taken place.  
(f) The date of the most recent review or revision of operating procedures. 
      - December 21, 2023
(g) The date of the most recent review or revision of training programs
      - January 30, 2024

(c) The owner or operator shall update the safety information if a major change occurs that

List of Federal or state safety regulations applicable to GGT: 
   - Nevada Division of Environmental Protection  Chemical Accident Prevention Program (NDEP- 
      CAPP)  Nevada Administrative Code Section 459 (Permit to Construct issued May 5, 2023;

The date of completion of the most recent hazard review or update: 
   - A detailed process hazards and operability (HAZOP) review was completed on December 21, 
      2023. This review was conducted consistent with the Process Safety Management Standards 
      outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119(e).  

(1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the hazard review
   - All action items from HAZOP were completed as of December 13, 2023.
(2) Major hazards identified:
   - The following were the highest ranked risk findings from the HAZOP completed December 21, 
     2023:
       Ensure transfer volume is programmed into Accuload
  o Resolution: Acculoads have truck strapping charts in database to prepopulate max amount 
     allowed onto a truck trailer and cannot be bypassed by the driver or controller. Vapor return 
     line to propane bullets also would route any overfill product back into the bullets. 
      Program HH (high high-pressure alarm) on PIT-4235 (pressure indicator, typical) to close 
    upstream XV at rate TBD and stop associated pump, update C&E.
 o Resolution: If high high-pressure alarm occurs on startup or during the loading process, the 
     PLC will stop Pump 15 (propane outbound) to prevent an overpressure event. 
(3) Process controls in use
   - SCADA is used to control startup/shutdown of loading and unloading of propane/butane. Built 
      within this system are interlocks to prevent over pressure

Executive Summary

Section 1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

GGT is dedicated to ensuring the safety of its facility, personnel, and surrounding community through robust fire protection and emergency response systems. These systems comprise: 
               Fire Alarm and Detection Systems
               Notification Appliances 
               Manual Pull Stations
               Flame Detection Cameras 
               Gas Detection Detectors
               Heat Detection Systems 
               Facility Emergency Shut?Down System
               Uninterruptible Backup Power System
               Fire Suppression Systems, including fire department connections for water and foam 
                      trailer operated by the Storey Country fire department. 
               Operating procedures and loading interlock system requiring grounding of rail cars 
                      (during unloading) and trucks (during loading) to prevent static discharge 
               Portable fire extinguishers
               Fire Water Supply 
               Physical barriers / bollards

Section 2  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Golden Gate Terminal, LLC (GGT) is located at 300 Ireland Drive, McCarran, Storey County, Nevada. GGT is a fuel storage and distribution facility and includes a series of atmospheric tanks (none of which contain Risk Management Plan-regulated substances) on an upper bench parallel with a rail spur and a series of bullet tanks on the lower bench of the property. The bullet tanks on the lower grade contain propane (CAS 74-98-6) and butane (CAS 106-97-8), the only RMP-regulated substances at the site.  The bullet tanks are loaded from rail cars and unloaded to trucks at GGTs loading rack. Butane will be routed to the Golden Gate transmit facility immediately adjacent to the south for the purpose of blending with gasoline.
